Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: An Integrated Research and Education Program in Physics of Heavy Hadrons
Award.AbstractNarration:
The PI proposes to study properties of B-mesons with the aim of extracting
fundamental parameters from precision data obtained at B-factories and other
accelerators. He will perform detailed calculations of B-Bbar mixing and
develop factorization theorems for the two-body decays of B-mesons into a
charmonium state plus a light meson. In this way he plans to separate the
effects of strong interaction matrix elements from those of fundamental
parameters such as CKM matrix elements.

In the broader aspects of the proposal, the PI plans an active program of
outreach to African-American students and other under-represented groups in
Detroit schools. In particular he will establish a network of computers in
the schools which will be used to train students during the school day and
to perform particle physics calculations at other times. He will also be involved in the local REU and RET programs and develop courses on the ?History of the Universe? to instruct high school teachers and students about particle physics and astrophysics and cosmology.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit:


The goal of this project was to explore the interplay of long- and short-distance strong dynamics and its effect on the extraction of information about fundamental electroweak parameters from experimental data obtained at high energy accelerators in the US and abroad. The research supported by this grant allowed applications of symmetry relations and techniques of Effective Field Theories (EFT) to the systems of mesons containing beauty and charm quarks. The program produced many results, described in 18 refereed publications.

This research has, for the first time, applied EFT techniques to gain more insight into several surprising experimental discoveries, such as a (presumably) molecular state of two elementary particles of integral spin, the X(3872). This method enables applications of symmetry techniques to studies of those unusual systems. Another important outcome was a method to study New Physics using the lifetime difference of heavy mesons. It was proven that, contrary to naive expectations, in the charm quark system, this observable can be dominated by unknown New Physics contributions. The idea was also applied to beauty quark systems.
 
Another important outcome was an important realization that entire classes of New Physics models could be better constrained by correlating measurements in different systems. For example, combination of meson oscillation and rare decay data probe unknown heavy degrees of freedom, whose mass is greater than the states that can be possibly produced at Large Hadron Collider (LHC). Alternatively, light Dark Matter (DM) properties can be constrained in a combination of data from astrophysics, direct detection experiments and decays of heavy mesons. Finally, we addressed some astrophysical surprises, such as generation of antimatter (positrons) in the vicinity of black holes.

The results of this research are summarized in a numerous journal and conference articles.



Broader Impact:


This program included a comprehensive educational and outreach component. The PI took over Wayne State's Research Experience for Undergraduates (REU) program as a Program Director, which trains approximately ten undergraduate students a year in astrophysics, particle and nuclear physics. A new yearly recurring introductory lecture on particle physics was developed within the set of new lectures for the preparation of REU students for their summer program.

Many problems in high energy physics and astrophysics are very computationally intense. In order for the U.S. to maintain its pre-eminent role in science, it is crucial that we begin, at an early age, to introduce our future scientists and engineers to the concept of computational science. A program in scientific computing for high school students, High School Distributed Scientific Computing (HiSchool DISCO), with two research computing clusters, was established in between WSU and the Roeper School with an eye for extending the project to include more local schools. The research has also trained three graduate students. One (A. Badin) went on to become a postdoctoral fellow at Duke University, another one (G. Yeghiyan) became a Visiting Assistant Professor  at Grand Valley State University, while the third one (M. AlFiky) received a permanent Lectureship at Ain Shams University in Egypt. Additionally, several undergraduate students were trained.
